exercise.name: Wall Triceps and Lat Stretch
exercise.whatItDoes: Increases flexibility and range of motion in the triceps, latissimus dorsi (lats), and shoulders, helping to improve overhead mobility and reduce tension in the upper back.

executionSteps.step: Stand next to a wall and raise one arm overhead, bending the elbow so your hand rests behind your neck.
Place your bent elbow and forearm flat against the wall, keeping your body close.
Slowly lean your upper body into the wall and push your hips slightly away to deepen the stretch along the side of your torso and tricep.
Maintain a steady breath and hold the stretch for 20–30 seconds.
Release and switch sides, repeating for the other arm.

commonMistakes.mistake: Shrugging the shoulder toward the ear; actively try to keep the shoulder relaxed and down.
Bouncing or forcing the stretch with jerky movements; the stretch should be slow and controlled.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively off the wall if the body is against the wall.

exercise.name: Standing Dumbbell Bicep Curl
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the biceps brachii, brachialis, and brachioradialis to build mass and strength in the arms.

executionSteps.step: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing forward (supinated grip).
Keep your elbows pinned close to your sides and squeeze your abs for stability.
Exhale and curl the dumbbells upward toward your shoulders, rotating your wrists slightly (supinating the pinky) to maximize the bicep contraction at the top.
Squeeze your biceps at the peak contraction, then slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position with control, maintaining tension.

commonMistakes.mistake: Swinging or using aggressive, jerky movements (momentum/cheating) to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to drift forward, which shifts the work to the front deltoids.
Not twisting the pinky through at the top of the curl for a full bicep contraction.

exercise.name: Standing Cable Crossover
exercise.whatItDoes: An isolation exercise that primarily targets the sternal (lower/middle) head of the pectoralis major, emphasizing the adduction function of the chest for definition.

executionSteps.step: Set the cable pulleys to a high position, grab a handle in each hand, and step forward into a staggered stance, leaning your torso slightly forward.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows (15–30°) and retract your shoulder blades to open your chest.
Exhale and bring the handles down and across your body's midline, contracting the chest fully until your hands or biceps touch your chest.
At the end of the repetition, squeeze your shoulders down (depress) to fully light up the chest.
Return slowly to the starting position for a full stretch, controlling the weight.

commonMistakes.mistake: Stopping the movement before bringing the handles across the body's midline for full adduction.
Rounding the shoulders forward, which limits full pec contraction.
Locking the arms completely straight; keep a slight bend in the elbow.

exercise.name: Seated Overhead Rope Pulldown (Lat Focus)
exercise.whatItDoes: Helps establish a better mind-to-muscle connection with the lats by performing the pulldown in a seated, isolated position, emphasizing the stretch and contraction of the latissimus dorsi.

executionSteps.step: Position a short bench facing a high cable pulley and attach a rope. Sit on the bench and grasp the rope attachment with both hands (palms facing in).
Keep a slight bend in your elbows and maintain a stable torso, extending the rope overhead.
Pull the rope down and slightly toward your sides by driving your elbows down, focusing on contracting the lats.
Pause briefly at the bottom of the movement.
Slowly return the rope to the overhead position for a full stretch, controlling the eccentric phase.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using momentum or swinging the body to move the weight.
Using too much bicep to pull the weight down instead of initiating the pull with the lats.
Not controlling the weight on the way up (eccentric phase).

exercise.name: Side Lying Foam Roll (IT Band)
exercise.whatItDoes: A self-myofascial release technique used to reduce tension and tightness in the iliotibial (IT) band, hips, and surrounding muscles, which can help relieve knee and hip pain.

executionSteps.step: Lie on your side with the foam roller positioned just below your hip bone (greater trochanter).
Support your body with your hands and use your top leg, bent in front of you, for stability and to adjust pressure.
Roll slowly from the hip down to your knee.
Pause on any particularly tight or sore spots for 20-30 seconds to allow the tissue to release.
Repeat on the other side.

commonMistakes.mistake: Rolling directly over the hip bone (greater trochanter), which can cause discomfort.
Rolling too quickly without pausing on trigger points.
Believing you are 'stretching' the IT band itself (you are targeting the surrounding musculature like the TFL and glutes).

exercise.name: Standing Calf Raise
exercise.whatItDoes: Primarily targets the gastrocnemius muscle (with the knee straight), strengthening the calves and improving ankle stability and explosiveness.

executionSteps.step: Stand tall, holding a dumbbell in one hand (or both, or use a machine). Stand with the balls of your feet on an elevated surface, heels hanging off, for a full range of motion.
Keep your knees straight (gently squeeze the thigh muscle) and your torso upright.
Slowly lower your heels down towards the ground to get a full stretch in the calves, controlling the eccentric movement for 2–3 seconds.
Press powerfully through the balls of your feet to raise your body as high as possible, aiming for a peak contraction at the top.

commonMistakes.mistake: Rushing the movement or bouncing (using the elastic energy of the Achilles tendon instead of the calf muscles).
Bending the knees to create momentum, which takes tension off the gastrocnemius.
Rolling out onto the ankles or letting the body lean to the outside.
Not achieving a full range of motion by stopping short on the descent.

exercise.name: Standing Dumbbell Bicep Curl (Full Body Icon)
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the biceps brachii, brachialis, and brachioradialis to build mass and strength in the arms.

executionSteps.step: Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing forward (supinated grip).
Keep your elbows pinned close to your sides and squeeze your abs for stability.
Exhale and curl the dumbbells upward toward your shoulders, rotating your wrists slightly (supinating the pinky) to maximize the bicep contraction at the top.
Squeeze your biceps at the peak contraction, then slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position with control, maintaining tension.

commonMistakes.mistake: Swinging or using aggressive, jerky movements (momentum/cheating) to lift the weight.
Allowing the elbows to drift forward, which shifts the work to the front deltoids.
Not twisting the pinky through at the top of the curl for a full bicep contraction.

exercise.name: Wide Grip Lat Pulldown
exercise.whatItDoes: A fundamental back exercise that primarily targets the latissimus dorsi, building back width and thickness, with secondary involvement from the biceps and rear delts.

executionSteps.step: Adjust the knee pad so you are secured tightly. Grab the bar with a wide overhand grip.
Depress your shoulders (pull them down) and lean back slightly (around 15-20 degrees) with your chest up.
Exhale and drive your elbows down towards your sides and back, bringing the bar to your upper chest/collarbone area. Focus on contracting your lats.
Pause and squeeze at the bottom position.
Control the bar slowly back up to the starting position until your arms are fully extended, feeling a full stretch in the lats.

commonMistakes.mistake: Stopping the movement short (not driving the elbows down and in).
Using momentum or swinging the body to move the weight.
Allowing the shoulders to shrug up towards the ears at the top of the movement.
Not fully stretching the lats on the ascent.

exercise.name: Seated Barbell Overhead Press
exercise.whatItDoes: A compound exercise that builds strength and mass in all three heads of the deltoids (shoulders), as well as the triceps and upper chest.

executionSteps.step: Sit upright on a bench with back support inside a power rack, adjusting the bar height to neck/upper chest level.
Take a full grip slightly wider than shoulder-width, and unrack the bar so it rests across the front of your shoulders/base of your neck.
Ensure your forearms are vertical and your wrists and elbows stay directly under the bar.
Exhale and press the bar straight up overhead until your arms are almost fully locked out.
Gently push your head "through the window" (just enough to finish with the bar over your shoulders).
Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position on your shoulders.

commonMistakes.mistake: Overarching the lower back excessively while pressing.
Not using a full range of motion or failing to fully lock out the elbows at the top.
Allowing the elbows to roll too far forward in the bottom position.

exercise.name: Kneeling Cable Crunch
exercise.whatItDoes: An isolation exercise that effectively targets the rectus abdominis (six-pack muscle) by performing weighted spinal flexion, maximizing muscle activation under load.

executionSteps.step: Set the cable pulley to the highest setting and attach a rope. Kneel facing the machine and grasp the rope, holding it by your head/forehead.
Bring your hips slightly back so your body is leaning forward, creating tension on the abs.
Exhale and crunch your torso down towards your knees, focusing on spinal flexion (rounding your back and contracting your abs) rather than just pushing with your arms.
Keep your elbows in towards your sides and squeeze your abs at the bottom.
Slowly return to the starting position, allowing the abs to stretch without fully relaxing the tension.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using the hips/legs to swing or pull down (using momentum) instead of the abdominal muscles.
Pulling the rope down using the arms/lats instead of focusing on spinal flexion.
Not achieving a full contraction or range of motion.

exercise.name: Seated Resistance Band Abduction
exercise.whatItDoes: An isolation exercise that activates and strengthens the hip abductors, primarily the gluteus medius and minimus, improving hip stability and knee tracking. Often used as a warm-up or pre-exhaustion movement.

executionSteps.step: Sit on the edge of a bench and place a resistance band just above your knees.
Place your feet flat on the floor, keeping your back straight and hands resting lightly on the bench for support.
Exhale and slowly push your knees outward against the resistance of the band, separating your legs and contracting your side glutes.
Pause briefly at the point of maximum contraction.
Control the movement back to the starting position, maintaining constant tension on the band.

commonMistakes.mistake: Allowing the feet to roll inward or outward; keep the feet flat and planted.
Rounding the back or leaning forward excessively.
Using jerky or fast movements; the movement should be slow and controlled.

exercise.name: Smith Machine Upright Row
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the medial and anterior heads of the deltoids (shoulders) and the trapezius (traps). Using the Smith Machine enforces strict form and balance.

executionSteps.step: Stand facing the Smith Machine bar, taking a medium-width grip (hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width).
Stand tall with the chest up and keep the core tight.
Exhale and pull the bar straight up toward your chin, leading with your elbows. Keep the bar close to your body.
Stop the upward movement when your elbows are level with or slightly above your shoulders.
Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position, controlling the weight throughout the eccentric phase.

commonMistakes.mistake: Pulling the bar too high, which can cause shoulder impingement (limit the pull to chin height or lower).
Using too wide of a grip, which decreases the range of motion.
Shrugging the shoulders excessively; focus on lifting the bar with the deltoids.

exercise.name: Barbell Squat (High Bar)
exercise.whatItDoes: A compound movement targeting the entire lower body—quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings—while also building core and lower back strength. The high-bar position places slightly more emphasis on the quads.

executionSteps.step: Set the barbell in a rack slightly below shoulder height. Step under and place the bar high on your traps, grasping it firmly with a medium grip.
Unrack the bar and take 1-2 steps back. Position your feet slightly wider than hip-width, toes pointing slightly out (15-30 degrees).
Take a deep breath, brace your core, and initiate the descent by breaking at the hips and knees simultaneously.
Squat down until your hips are below your knees (or as low as your mobility allows), keeping your chest up and back straight.
Drive through your mid-foot/heels to stand back up, exhaling as you reach the top.

commonMistakes.mistake: Allowing the lower back to round (butt wink) at the bottom of the squat, which can stress the spine.
Letting the knees cave inward (valgus collapse); actively push the knees out over the feet.
Lifting the hips faster than the shoulders on the ascent (Good Morning squatting the weight).

exercise.name: Smith Machine Good Morning
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the entire posterior chain, primarily the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back (erector spinae). The Smith Machine stabilizes the bar, forcing strict hip hinge movement.

executionSteps.step: Set the Smith Machine bar to shoulder height. Load the bar and step under it, resting it high on your upper traps.
Take a medium-width stance and unrack the bar.
Initiate the movement by taking a deep breath and bracing your core, pushing your hips straight backward as if closing a car door with your glutes.
Maintain a slight bend in your knees and a neutral spine, lowering your torso until it is nearly parallel to the floor or until you feel a deep stretch in your hamstrings.
Powerfully contract your glutes and hamstrings to reverse the movement and stand back up straight, exhaling at the top.

commonMistakes.mistake: Rounding the back (losing the neutral spine position); keep the back flat and core tight.
Excessively bending the knees, which turns the exercise into a squat.
Not controlling the descent; the movement should be slow and deliberate for a proper stretch.

exercise.name: Seated Smith Machine Calf Raise
exercise.whatItDoes: An isolation movement that targets the soleus muscle (located beneath the gastrocnemius), which is best activated when the knee is bent, promoting overall calf thickness and endurance.

executionSteps.step: Set a bench inside a Smith Machine and place a wooden block or bumper plate under the bar. Sit on the bench and rest the bar across the tops of your thighs, just above your knees.
Place the balls of your feet on the elevated surface, letting your heels hang off for a full stretch.
Unrack the bar and hold it steady with your hands.
Slowly lower your heels down towards the floor to maximize the stretch in the calves.
Powerfully raise your heels up as high as possible, squeezing the calves at the peak contraction.

commonMistakes.mistake: Relying on momentum to move the weight rather than slow, deliberate muscle contraction.
Not using a full range of motion (failing to stretch fully at the bottom or contract fully at the top).
Allowing the knees to move too much during the movement.

exercise.name: Supine Crunch (Hands Behind Head)
exercise.whatItDoes: A fundamental exercise to strengthen the rectus abdominis (six-pack muscles), focusing on contracting the upper abdominal area to bring the rib cage toward the pelvis.

executionSteps.step: Lie flat on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, about hip-width apart.
Place your hands lightly behind your head, or cross them over your chest (do not pull on your neck).
Exhale and slowly curl your upper body (head and shoulders) off the floor by contracting your abdominal muscles, bringing your rib cage toward your pelvis.
Pause and squeeze the abdominals at the peak of the movement.
Inhale and slowly lower your upper body back down to the starting position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Pulling on the neck to lift the head, which can cause strain.
Lifting the entire torso off the floor (like a sit-up), which engages the hip flexors too much.
Rushing the movement; maintain control for muscle engagement.

exercise.name: Wall Tricep and Lat Stretch
exercise.whatItDoes: Increases flexibility and range of motion in the triceps, latissimus dorsi (lats), and shoulders, helping to improve overhead mobility and reduce tension in the upper back.

executionSteps.step: Stand next to a wall and raise one arm overhead, bending the elbow so your hand rests behind your neck.
Place your bent elbow and forearm flat against the wall, keeping your body close.
Slowly lean your upper body into the wall and push your hips slightly away to deepen the stretch along the side of your torso and tricep.
Maintain a steady breath and hold the stretch for 20–30 seconds.
Release and switch sides, repeating for the other arm.

commonMistakes.mistake: Shrugging the shoulder toward the ear; actively try to keep the shoulder relaxed and down.
Bouncing or forcing the stretch with jerky movements; the stretch should be slow and controlled.
Allowing the lower back to arch excessively off the wall if the body is against the wall.

exercise.name: Standing Barbell Tricep Extension (French Press)
exercise.whatItDoes: Primarily targets the long head of the triceps brachii, maximizing the stretch on the muscle by placing the arms overhead.

executionSteps.step: Stand tall and hold an EZ curl bar (or straight bar) overhead with an overhand grip, hands about shoulder-width apart.
Keep your elbows tucked in and pointing straight forward. Bracing your core and glutes helps prevent back arching.
Inhale and slowly lower the bar behind your head by bending only at the elbows.
Stretch the triceps fully, then exhale and forcefully extend your arms, using your triceps to press the bar back to the starting overhead position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Flaring the elbows out to the sides, which reduces tricep isolation and can stress the elbow joint.
Allowing the head or upper body to move forward or backward (using momentum or arching the back).
Not achieving a full range of motion (stopping short on the descent).

exercise.name: Wide Grip Pull Up (Cable Machine Assisted)
exercise.whatItDoes: A compound upper body exercise that targets the lats for back width and thickness, using a cable machine to provide assistance for lifters who cannot perform full unassisted reps.

executionSteps.step: Set up a resistance band or cable machine attachment for assistance on a high pull-up bar.
Grasp the bar with a wide, overhand grip.
Hang with arms fully extended and shoulders shrugged up, then initiate the pull by depressing the shoulder blades (pulling them down and back) and slightly arching the chest up.
Pull your body upward until your chin clears the bar, focusing on driving your elbows down and back.
Slowly lower your body back down to a dead hang, ensuring a full stretch in the lats.

commonMistakes.mistake: Pulling with the biceps instead of initiating the movement with the back muscles (lats).
Not going through a full range of motion (stopping short on the descent or failing to get the chin over the bar).
Using jerky or swinging motions.

exercise.name: Kneeling Ab Wheel Rollout
exercise.whatItDoes: An advanced core exercise that highly activates the entire core (rectus abdominis, obliques, transverse abdominis) and hip flexors, requiring significant anti-extension strength.

executionSteps.step: Kneel on a mat with your knees hip-width apart and grasp the ab wheel handles with an overhand grip.
Keep your back straight and core braced, ensuring your hips are slightly tucked (posterior pelvic tilt) to prevent the lower back from arching.
Slowly roll the wheel forward, extending your body until you are close to the floor, maintaining the rigid, braced posture.
Pause briefly at the point of maximum extension you can safely control.
Contract your core and lats to pull your body back to the starting kneeling position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Letting the lower back arch (hip sag) on the descent, which can lead to injury.
Not extending far enough; push the limits of your range of motion while maintaining form.
Using momentum rather than slow, controlled tension.

exercise.name: Barbell Front Squat
exercise.whatItDoes: A variation of the squat that places the barbell across the front of the shoulders, forcing a more upright torso and heavily targeting the quadriceps and upper back/core stability.

executionSteps.step: Set the barbell in a rack slightly below shoulder height. Place the bar high on the front of your shoulders (deltoids) and secure it with an Olympic clean grip or cross-arm grip.
Unrack the bar and take 1-2 steps back. Position your feet shoulder-width apart, toes pointing slightly out.
Brace your core and keep your elbows pointed forward (to create a solid shelf for the bar).
Squat down by pushing your knees forward and keeping your torso as upright as possible, descending until your hips are below parallel.
Drive through your mid-foot to stand back up, maintaining the upright posture.

commonMistakes.mistake: Letting the elbows drop, causing the bar to roll forward off the shoulders.
Rounding the upper back; maintain tension and keep the chest proud.
Not being able to squat deep enough due to mobility limitations in the ankles, hips, or upper back.

exercise.name: Incline Bench Supported Sissy Squat
exercise.whatItDoes: An isolation exercise that places extreme tension on the quadriceps, specifically emphasizing the rectus femoris muscle by training it in a simultaneously lengthened (hip extension) and flexed (knee flexion) position.

executionSteps.step: Set up an incline bench and stand facing away from it. Hold a weight plate to your chest (optional) and lean back, placing your hand on the bench for balance.
Keep your hips fully extended and your body in a straight line from your shoulders to your knees throughout the movement.
Slowly bend your knees, letting them travel far forward while descending your body backward.
Descend as far as comfortable, then powerfully push back up to the starting position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Letting the hips move out of full extension (allowing the butt to stick out) as you descend, which takes tension off the rectus femoris.
Using jerky or fast movements; the exercise should be slow and controlled to maintain tension.

exercise.name: Incline Dumbbell Fly
exercise.whatItDoes: Isolates the upper pectoral muscles with a focus on the stretching phase to build upper chest width.

executionSteps.step: Lie on an incline bench holding dumbbells directly above your chest, palms facing each other.
Keep a slight bend in your elbows to protect the joint.
Lower the weights out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest.
Reverse the motion to bring the dumbbells back to the top.
Stop just before weights touch to maintain tension.

commonMistakes.mistake: Turning the movement into a press by bending elbows too much.
Lowering the weights too far, risking shoulder injury.
Touching the weights together at the top.
Using too much weight and compromising form.

exercise.name: Decline Dumbbell Bench Press
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the lower pectoral muscles and triceps more effectively than the flat bench press.

executionSteps.step: Secure your legs at the end of the decline bench and lie back.
Start with weights at shoulder width, arms extended above your chest.
Lower the weights slowly until your elbows are at a 90-degree angle.
Press the weights back up to the starting position.
Squeeze the chest at the top.

commonMistakes.mistake: Setting the bench angle too steep.
Flaring elbows out too wide.
Using momentum to push the weight up.
Banging dumbbells together at the top.

exercise.name: Barbell Rear Shrug
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the upper and middle trapezius muscles, improving upper back thickness and posture.

executionSteps.step: Stand holding a barbell behind your thighs with an overhand grip.
Keep your arms straight and chest up.
Elevate your shoulders toward your ears as high as possible.
Squeeze the traps at the top for a second.
Lower the bar back down under control.

commonMistakes.mistake: Rolling the shoulders forward or backward.
Bending the elbows to lift the weight.
Jutting the head forward.
Using excessive weight limiting range of motion.

exercise.name: Incline Cable Pulldown
exercise.whatItDoes: Provides a strict angle for latissimus dorsi isolation, minimizing momentum and maximizing the stretch.

executionSteps.step: Set a bench to an incline and position it in front of a high pulley cable.
Sit facing away from the machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip.
Lean back into the bench and pull the bar down towards your upper chest.
Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom.
Slowly return the bar to the top.

commonMistakes.mistake: Arching the lower back excessively.
Pulling with the biceps rather than the back.
Bringing the bar too low.
Using momentum to jerk the weight down.

exercise.name: Overhead Triceps Stretch
exercise.whatItDoes: Improves flexibility in the triceps and shoulders, reducing muscle tightness.

executionSteps.step: Stand or sit upright. Reach one arm overhead.
Bend the elbow so your hand reaches down the center of your back.
Use the opposite hand to gently pull the raised elbow toward your head.
Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.
Switch arms and repeat.

commonMistakes.mistake: Pulling the elbow too aggressively.
Arching the back.
Craning the neck forward.
Holding the breath.

exercise.name: Single Leg Dumbbell Calf Raise
exercise.whatItDoes: Isolates the calf muscles unilaterally to correct imbalances and build lower leg mass.

executionSteps.step: Stand on one leg while holding a dumbbell in the hand on the same side.
Keep your core tight and your standing leg slightly straight.
Raise your heel as high as possible by pushing through the ball of your foot.
Pause at the top, then slowly lower the heel.
Complete reps on one side before switching.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using momentum or bouncing.
Not going through the full range of motion.
Leaning too far forward.
Bending the knee significantly.

exercise.name: Medicine Ball Push-Up
exercise.whatItDoes: Increases core activation and shoulder stability while targeting the chest and triceps.

executionSteps.step: Place a large medicine ball on the floor.
Get into a push-up position with both hands balancing on the ball.
Keep your body rigid and core engaged.
Lower your chest slowly towards the ball.
Push explosively back up to the starting position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Poor core stability causing hips to sway.
Hands slipping off the ball.
Neck dropping down towards the ball.
Performing reps too quickly.

exercise.name: Sphinx Push-Up
exercise.whatItDoes: An advanced bodyweight movement that isolates the triceps by extending the elbows from a plank position.

executionSteps.step: Start in a plank position with forearms on the ground.
Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels.
Press your palms into the floor to lift your elbows off the ground.
Extend arms fully.
Slowly lower your elbows back to the starting plank position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Allowing the hips to sag.
Flaring the elbows out wide.
Placing hands too far forward.
Using momentum to jerk up.

exercise.name: Resistance Band Calf Press
exercise.whatItDoes: Strengthens the calves using variable resistance, great for warming up or rehabilitation.

executionSteps.step: Sit on the floor with legs extended.
Loop a resistance band around the balls of your feet.
Press your toes forward against the resistance of the band.
Pause at the peak extension.
Slowly return your toes toward your shins.

commonMistakes.mistake: Letting the band slip off the feet.
Bending knees excessively.
Not maintaining tension on the band.
Performing the movement too fast.

exercise.name: Diamond Push-Up
exercise.whatItDoes: A push-up variation that shifts focus to the triceps and inner chest by narrowing the hand placement.

executionSteps.step: Get into a push-up position.
Place hands together forming a diamond shape with thumbs and index fingers.
Lower your chest towards your hands, keeping elbows tucked.
Push back up to the starting position.
Keep your core tight throughout the movement.

commonMistakes.mistake: Allowing elbows to flare out excessively.
Letting hips sag.
Not going down low enough.
Hand placement not being centered under the chest.

exercise.name: Smith Machine Shrug
exercise.whatItDoes: Isolates the trapezius muscles to build upper back thickness and neck stability.

executionSteps.step: Set the bar height to just below your waist.
Grip the bar with hands shoulder-width apart.
Lift your shoulders toward your ears as high as possible.
Pause at the top and squeeze the traps.
Lower the bar slowly to the starting position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Rolling the shoulders (keep the motion vertical).
Using too much weight and limiting range of motion.
Jutting the head forward.
Bending the elbows to help lift the weight.

exercise.name: Dumbbell Front Squat
exercise.whatItDoes: Targets the quads, glutes, and core while placing less stress on the lower back than a back squat.

executionSteps.step: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells at your shoulders.
Keep your chest up and elbows high.
Lower your hips back and down until thighs are parallel to the floor.
Drive through your heels to return to the standing position.
Keep your core braced throughout the movement.

commonMistakes.mistake: Letting the knees cave inward.
Rounding the upper back.
Dropping the elbows, causing the weight to pull you forward.
Lifting the heels off the ground.

exercise.name: Barbell Front Squat
exercise.whatItDoes: A squat variation that emphasizes the quadriceps due to the upright torso position. It also significantly challenges core and upper back strength for stability.

executionSteps.step: Load the barbell and place it across the front of your shoulders, using a clean grip or crossed-arm grip to secure it.
Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, chest high, and elbows pointing forward.
Descend slowly into a squat, keeping your torso as upright as possible. Go as deep as mobility allows without rounding your back.
Drive through your heels and push your hips forward to return to the standing position.

commonMistakes.mistake: Dropping the elbows, causing the chest to collapse and the back to round.
Letting the weight roll forward onto the fingertips (losing the rack position).
Failing to maintain a stable, upright core throughout the lift.
